abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Integrated Marine and
            Coastal Resources Management Project (GRIMAC) for Senegal
            were as follows: outcome was unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was high, Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Sustainable Management of
            Fish Resources Project (GDRH) for Senegal were as follows:
            outcome was highly unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was high, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was unsatisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: reforming the fisheries
            sector is politically sensitive and a long term pursuit,
            best suited to a phased programmatic approach in which
            sustained support is ensured over a series of operations.
            Operationalizing co-management requires actions at both
            local and national level, lack of synchronization between
            the two can disrupt implementation and the motivation of key
            actors. Supporting alternative revenue generating activities
            can potentially reduce the poverty-conservation tradeoff by
            making up for lost income or subsistence opportunities that
            stem from reduced resource access caused by project
            activities. The Bank has continued to support Senegal in
            reforming its fisheries sector beyond the close of the
            projects though the West Africa Regional Fisheries Program
            (WARFP). There was a delay of approximately one year between
            the end of the GRIMAC and GDRH projects and the resumption
            of activities under the West Africa Regional Fisheries
            Program (WARFP).
